item.title: Designing for support teams
item.description: Support agents spend their entire lives using the same software. Their needs are very different from consumer software. Here are some things to keep in mind.

item.title: Twitter's Sith and Jedi
item.description: In Star Wars, hate gives the Sith power from the dark side of the Force beyond what the Jedi can reach. But when they lean into hate, they lose their soul to it. Twitter offers the same bargain as the Force.

item.title: Enterprise sales meets product development
item.description: What I’ve learned from selling enterprises while developing a new product. This is less of a guide and more of a cautionary tale.

item.description: Lessons from AWS S3 and others on how to price APIs.

item.title: Semantic gaps
item.description: Swedish has a specific word for each of the four grandparents: mormor, morfar, farmor, farfar. English doesn’t. So when you mention your 'grandma' to a Swede, they are left wondering 'which grandma?' even if it is not relevant to the story. That is a semantic gap.

item.title: Notes on UX and LLM integrations
item.description: I analyze 8 apps (ChatGPT, Notion, Perplexity, etc.) that use or integrate LLM and try to break down when and why they work well, or poorly.

item.title: How to: friction logs
item.description: Friction logs are a technique to improve your own products and understand others. You use the produdct the way a real user would and write down every single moment you experience some form of negative emotion.

item.title: Lieutenants are the limiting reagent
item.description: Why don't software companies ship more products? Why do they move more slowly as they grow? What do we mean when we say "this company lacks focus"?

item.title: Interfaces for logical migrations
item.description: This post explains how you can use interfaces to make data model and database migrations easier.

item.title: Everybody is the main character
item.description: People are motivated and engaged with the work only if they feel in charge of their own destiny. Make it clear to them that they are!

item.title: Team-oriented, outcome-oriented
item.description: Some people care about helping their team. Others care about achieving outcomes. It is important to know who is who.

item.title: Breaking changes in JSON APIs
item.description: A collection of common breaking changes to JSON APIs for you to keep in mind as you design.

item.title: How to avoid breaking APIs
item.description: The main trick is to design them with extension in mind so that you won't have to break them later.

item.title: Payments vs Transfers
item.description: Transfer means to move money but payment means "exchanging goods or services". A payment system has a lot more requirements than a transfer system and I rarely see the crypto ecosystem acknowledge these when building "payment" products.

item.title: Math intuitions on variance
item.description: This is a supplement to High Variance Management, where I build some intuition on the different probability distributions involved.

item.title: APIs as ladders
item.description: APIs are hard to learn. If you think about the learning curve of your API, you can design one that works for beginners, novices, and experts.
